title: Icelandic beer spa brews up relaxing baths
description:
(4 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
Forget bubble baths, how about beer baths?
Iceland recently opened its first beer spa. Visitors soak in 40-degree bubbling beer, yeast and hops.
STORYLINE:
The tiny Icelandic village of Arskogssandur, around 400 kilometres northeast of Reykjavik, is home to the country's oldest working microbrewery.
But since June, it's had a new neighbour - the volcanic country's first beer spa.
Bjorbodin Spa houses seven indoor beer tubs, they're large enough to fit two people each. It is for adults only.
But don't try drinking it - beer baths are warmed to 40 degrees-Celsius (100 degrees Fahrenheit) meaning most of the alcohol evaporates.
Soffia Sigurdasdottir is Bjorbodin Spa's head beautician. She claims there are many benefits to being submerged in warm beer. 
"In the beer baths we use fresh water from our mountains, young beer, brewed yeast and hops," she says. 
"The yeast and the young beer is specially rich and has high level of almost the whole range of vitamin B, which is revitalising for skin and hair. 
"And the hops have high levels of anti-oxidants, which are really good for the skin as well as have a good effect on the PH of your body."
Bathtubs are equipped with a tap of Kaldi, the local larger produced at the brewery next door.
Spa visitor Thorsteinn Ragnarsson is a business entrepreneur from the nearby city of Akureyri.
"It's a very new experience for me," he says.
"I have never thought about beer as something to bathe in. I've always thought about beer just as something to drink. And then I heard about the benefits of the beer bathing and I just had to try it out."
Beer spas are particularly popular in the Czech Republic, where there is a rich tradition of beer breweries and accompanying spas.
Another visitor, Dana Antonsdottir is a worker from a nearby village.
"I feel very relaxed, the first thing," she says. 
"And I don't know how to put words on it, it's soft and relaxed. Like yeah."
It's claimed the effect on the skin is best enhanced by not showering off the liquid until some hours later.
After soaking in the tub, guests are sent to a relaxation room for around 25 minutes to let the liquids soak in.
But the spa recommends waiting several hours before showering.
A single bath is priced at 6,900 Icelandic kroner (approx. $65 USD). A couple's bath costs 13,000 Icelandic kroner (approx. $123 USD).
